poem:
**Mother's Gloop**

Staggering from play to stage,  
Sara grapples with a strange gloop,  
life's sticky residue, motherhood's echo—  
banish the self, bring forth tales  
like blossoms through winter's crust.  
In laughter's bright rebellion, she finds—  
even amid the cluttered rubble—  
the gleam of her own distant star.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sara Pascoe: I Am a Strange Gloop review – terrific standup’s uphill struggles Her last tour, Success Story, found Sara Pascoe in the loved-up phase of recent new parenthood. Reader, she has now put that phase behind her. I Am a Strange Gloop finds our host staggering shell-shocked from the soft play area to the stage, with battle-hardened tales to tell from motherhood’s frontline. Ruthlessly banished from the centre of her own life, she now". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
